items.author: Tom Huddleston
items.content: This is the directorâ€™s most vivid, most emotional and humane film, and perhaps his best.

items.author: Jonathan Rosenbaum
items.content: Banned in France for 18 years, this masterpiece still packs a wallop, though nothing in it is as simple as it may first appear; audiences are still arguing about the final sequence, which has been characterized as everything from a sentimental cop-out to the ultimate cynical twist.

items.author: Roger Ebert
items.content: Paths of Glory was the film by which Stanley Kubrick entered the ranks of great directors, never to leave them.

items.author: Peter Bradshaw
items.content: It is arguably the best film about the first world war, and still has a reasonable claim to being Stanley Kubrick's best film.

items.author: Wall Street Journal
items.content: One of the greatest war films ever made.

items.author: Daniel Green
items.content: Paths of Glory undoubtedly succeeds in both foreshadowing the bravura auteurism that was to come as well as lampooning the abhorrent bureaucracy that destroyed the lives of so many brave young men in Europe's trenches.

items.author: BBC
items.content: The searing Paths Of Glory continues to impress with its striking blend of formal brilliance, economical storytelling and emotional directness.

items.author: David Denby
items.content: The sardonic rhetoric may be laid on a little heavily at times, but the movie is blunt and scornfully brilliant.

items.author: Bosley Crowther
items.content: Mr. Kubrick has made it look terrific. The execution scene is one of the most craftily directed and emotionally lacerating that we have ever seen. But there are two troubling flaws in this picture, one in the realm of technique and the other in the realm of significance, which determine its larger, lasting worth.

items.author: Variety
items.content: While the subject is well handled and enacted in a series of outstanding characterizations, it seems dated and makes for grim screen fare.
